\chapter{ReadMe}
\label{\detokenize{readme:readme}}\label{\detokenize{readme::doc}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
\# EP\sphinxhyphen{}BOLFI

\sphinxAtStartPar
EP\sphinxhyphen{}BOLFI (Expectation Propagation with Bayesian Optimization for Likelihood\sphinxhyphen{}Free Inference) extends the simulator optimizer BOLFI with the data featurization of Expectation Propagation. EP\sphinxhyphen{}BOLFI inherits the advantages of both: high stability to measurement noise and considerable reduction of computational effort. The performance is one to two orders of magnitude better than Markov\sphinxhyphen{}Chain Monte Carlo, counted in the number of simulator evaluations required.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\#\# Documentation

\sphinxAtStartPar
{[}ep\_bolfi{]}(ep\_bolfi/) contains the EP\sphinxhyphen{}BOLFI algorithm, a few example models, and utility functions that cover fitting functions, datafile imports, dataset processing, and visualization. For further details, please refer to {[}the HTML documentation on GitLab Pages{]}(\sphinxurl{https://cec.pages.gitlab.dlr.de/bte/ep-bolfi/}).

\sphinxAtStartPar
\#\# Examples
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{The {[}examples{]}(examples/) currently comprise of the code used in the {[}EP\sphinxhyphen{}BOLFI publication{]}(\sphinxurl{https://doi.org/10.48550/arXiv.2208.03289}). Apart from the SPMe benchmark, they analyze a GITT dataset provided by BASF. You can find the dataset at the DOI {[}10.5281/zenodo.7478267{]}(\sphinxurl{https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.7478267}). If you wish to re\sphinxhyphen{}run the parameterization yourself, copy the contents of GITT\_data\_and\_parameterization\_info.zip into {[}examples{]}(examples/) first.}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To perform the SPMe benchmarks from Aitio et al., please use spme\_benchmark\_multimodal.py and spme\_benchmark\_unimodal.py. To calculate the tabulated results presented in the article, use evaluate\_spme\_benchmark\_confidence.py.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To preprocess the OCV curves, please use ocv\_from\_cccv\_and\_gitt.py.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To view the GITT data, please use measurement\_plot.py.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To estimate parameters from the GITT data from BASF, use run\_estimation.py, and after that collect\_gitt\_estimation\_results.py. This may take more than a week to run.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To get the tabulated results for the GITT parameterization, please use evaluate\_gitt\_estimation\_confidence.py.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To perform the verification of the GITT data parameterization, please use verify\_estimation.py. This may take more than a week to run.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To analyze the correlation matrix for the 7\sphinxhyphen{}parameter estimation, please use correlation\_visualization.py.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To plot the results from the GITT estimation procedure, please use gitt\_visualization.py.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To analyze the precision and reliability of the GITT estimation procedure, please use calculate\_experimental\_and\_simulated\_features.py. To plot this analysis, please use analytic\_vs\_epbolfi\_results.py and sensitivity\_visualization.py.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
To plot the joint resistance of the two exchange\sphinxhyphen{}current densities, please use joint\_resistance.py.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\#\# Using EP\sphinxhyphen{}BOLFI to process your measurements with your model

\sphinxAtStartPar
Please have a look at {[}the setup example{]}(examples/parameters/estimation/). {[}gitt\_basf.py{]}(examples/parameters/estimation/gitt\_basf.py) contains the preprocessing of the GITT dataset and a GITT simulator. {[}gitt.py{]}(examples/parameters/estimation/gitt.py) contains one possible definition of features in a GITT measurement. For performing the optimization, please have a look at run\_estimation.py. If you wish to re\sphinxhyphen{}use an optimization result as starting value, use .Q, .r, .Q\_features and .r\_features and pass them to the initialization of the EP\sphinxhyphen{}BOLFI object.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\#\# Installation

\sphinxAtStartPar
EP\sphinxhyphen{}BOLFI requires {[}Python 3.8 or greater{]}(\sphinxurl{https://www.python.org/downloads/}). Just download the newest Release .whl file and {[}requirements.txt{]}(requirements.txt). Install the dependencies with {[}requirements.txt{]}(requirements.txt) via {[}pip{]}(\sphinxurl{https://pypi.org/project/pip/}), then install the .whl file. In case you want to build the package from source, please refer to {[}CONTRIBUTING.md{]}(CONTRIBUTING.md\#building\sphinxhyphen{}from\sphinxhyphen{}source).

\sphinxAtStartPar
\#\#\# Using pip

\sphinxAtStartPar
Create a virtual environment and activate it. On Linux and Mac:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`bash
python3.9 \sphinxhyphen{}m venv ep\_bolfi
source ep\_bolfi/bin/activate
`}}
On Windows:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`powershell
py \sphinxhyphen{}3.9 \sphinxhyphen{}m venv ep\_bolfi
. .\textbackslash{}ep\_bolfi\textbackslash{}Scripts\textbackslash{}activate
`}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then install the dependencies and package:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`bash
pip install \sphinxhyphen{}r requirements.txt
pip install ep\_bolfi\sphinxhyphen{}\$\{VERSION\}\sphinxhyphen{}py3\sphinxhyphen{}none\sphinxhyphen{}any.whl
`}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\#\#\# Using {[}miniforge{]}(\sphinxurl{https://github.com/conda-forge/miniforge})

\sphinxAtStartPar
On Windows, first initialize conda to work with PowerShell, assuming you work with PowerShell:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`powershell
conda init powershell
`}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Create a new virtual environment:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`bash
conda create \sphinxhyphen{}n ep\_bolfi python=3.9
conda activate ep\_bolfi
`}}
and install the dependencies there. The fastest way is to use pip to install the packages:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`bash
pip install \sphinxhyphen{}r requirements.txt
`}}
If you want to use the conda package manager as much as possible, use these lines instead:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`bash
conda env update \sphinxhyphen{}\sphinxhyphen{}file ep\_bolfi.yml
pip install \sphinxhyphen{}r pip\_only\_requirements.txt
`}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then install the dependencies and package:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`bash
conda install ep\_bolfi\sphinxhyphen{}\$\{VERSION\}\sphinxhyphen{}py39\_0.tar.bz2
`}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\#\#\# Using the Kadi4Mat tools

\sphinxAtStartPar
The files in (ep\_bolfi/kadi\_tools) are command\sphinxhyphen{}line tools. These command\sphinxhyphen{}line tools are designed to interface with the database software {[}Kadi4Mat{]}(\sphinxurl{https://kadi.iam-cms.kit.edu/}), of which we have an internal instance running at (\sphinxurl{https://kadi-dlr.hiu-batteries.de/}).

\sphinxAtStartPar
In order to use these command\sphinxhyphen{}line tools in the workflow toolchain of Kadi4Mat, they are implemented with the library {[}xmlhelpy{]}(\sphinxurl{https://gitlab.com/iam-cms/workflows/xmlhelpy}) which extends the {[}Click{]}(\sphinxurl{https://github.com/pallets/click}) library for command\sphinxhyphen{}line tools with the option to generate machine\sphinxhyphen{}readable representations of command\sphinxhyphen{}line tools. You can find these representations in \sphinxtitleref{ep\_bolfi/kadi\_tools/xml\_representations}, but only when installing a Release. If they are missing in your installation, please refer to the manual instructions in {[}CONTRIBUTING.md{]}(CONTRIBUTING.md).

\sphinxAtStartPar
{[}KadiStudio{]}(\sphinxurl{https://bwsyncandshare.kit.edu/s/cJSZrE6fDTR6cLQ}) can import the .py files, or on a Kadi4Mat instance with the online workflow editor enabled, the .xml files can be imported by uploading them to any Record on the respective Kadi4Mat instance. The command\sphinxhyphen{}line tools are then available as building blocks for workflows.

\sphinxAtStartPar
For executing workflows that contain one of these tools, the command \sphinxtitleref{python} has to launch a Python environment with this library installed. Either bake the activation of said environment into the convenience scripts in the following section, or make your command line automatically activate it by following these steps.

\sphinxAtStartPar
On Linux:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`bash
nano \textasciitilde{}/.profile
`}}
Then add the following line to the bottom of the file:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`
source \textasciitilde{}/ep\_bolfi/bin/activate
`}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
On Windows:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`powershell
notepad \$((Split\sphinxhyphen{}Path \$profile \sphinxhyphen{}Parent) + "\textbackslash{}profile.ps1")
`}}
Then add the following line to the bottom of the text file:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`
. .\textbackslash{}ep\_bolfi\textbackslash{}Scripts\textbackslash{}activate
`}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In the case where spurious lines like “warning in …: failed to import cython module: falling back to numpy” show up and break workflow scripts, these are due to an unfortunate design decision in GPy. You need to install GPy from source like so to improve performance as well:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`bash
git clone https://github.com/SheffieldML/GPy.git
cd GPy
pip install .
`}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
For the smoothest installation experience, we recommend using the HPC JUSTUS 2.

\sphinxAtStartPar
\#\#\# Convenience scripts to execute Kadi4Mat workflows

\sphinxAtStartPar
Since {[}KadiStudio{]}(\sphinxurl{https://bwsyncandshare.kit.edu/s/cJSZrE6fDTR6cLQ}) is semi\sphinxhyphen{}usable at this point in time to work with Kadi4Mat workflows, there are two helper scripts in this repository for executing workflows automatically, including input interactions. First, install the libraries {[}process engine{]}(\sphinxurl{https://gitlab.com/iam-cms/workflows/process-engine}) and {[}process manager{]}(\sphinxurl{https://gitlab.com/iam-cms/workflows/process-manager}). We recommend Linux or using Linux indirectly via {[}WSL{]}(\sphinxurl{https://learn.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/wsl/install}) on Windows.
On Linux, (ep\_bolfi/utility/execute\_workflow\_locally.py) can be made into an executable with {[}PyInstaller{]}(\sphinxurl{https://pyinstaller.org/en/stable/}) that can be registered with your OS or browser to execute workflow files:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`bash
pip install pyinstaller
pyinstaller ep\_bolfi/utility/execute\_workflow\_locally.py
`}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
You then find the executable inside (dist/execute\_workflow\_locally/). Do not use (build), and move the whole folder (dist/execute\_workflow\_locally/) to where you want to store executable, as the executable depends on the folder contents.

\sphinxAtStartPar
On Windows, use (ep\_bolfi/utility/send\_workflow\_to\_wsl.py). It is a wrapper for the case where the process engine and process manager are installed within a WSL on Windows. First, make sure that you installed EP\sphinxhyphen{}BOLFI as described above first within WSL. The script assumes you did so within a virtual environment \textasciitilde{}/venv in WSL, like so:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`bash
pip install virtualenv
cd \textasciitilde{}
mkdir venv
virtualenv venv
source venv/bin/activate
pip/conda install ...
`}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then, instead of (ep\_bolfi/utility/execute\_workflow\_locally.py), you make an executable out of (ep\_bolfi/utility/send\_workflow\_to\_wsl.py) in Windows:

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{`cmd
pip install pyinstaller
pyinstaller ep\_bolfi/utility/send\_workflow\_to\_wsl.py
`}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Then move the folder (dist/send\_workflow\_to\_wsl/) to where you want to store the executable and then register the contained (send\_workflow\_to\_wsl.exe) with your OS or browser to open workflow files. Remember to install and activate {[}Xming{]}(\sphinxurl{http://www.straightrunning.com/XmingNotes/changes.php}) if you wish to have graphical outputs.

\sphinxlineitem{input\_data}{[}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pybamm.Solution}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pybamm.Simulation}}{]}

Solution or Simulation object from which to extract voltage

\sphinxlineitem{ax}{[}matplotlib Axis, optional{]}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The axis on which to put the plot. If None, a new figure and
axis is created.

\sphinxlineitem{show\_legend}{[}bool, optional{]}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Whether to display the legend. Default is True

\sphinxlineitem{split\_by\_electrode}{[}bool, optional{]}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Whether to show the overpotentials for the negative and positive
electrodes
separately. Default is False.

\sphinxlineitem{three\_electrode}{[}str, optional{]}
\sphinxAtStartPar
With None, does nothing (i.e., cell potentials are used). If
set to either ‘positive’ or ‘negative’, instead of cell
potentials, the base for the displayed voltage will be the
potential of the ‘positive’ or ‘negative’ electrode against a
reference electrode. For placement of said reference electrode,
please refer to “dimensionless\_reference\_electrode\_location”.

\sphinxlineitem{dimensionless\_reference\_electrode\_location}{[}float, optional{]}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The location of the reference electrode, given as a scalar
between 0 (placed at the point where negative electrode and
separator meet) and 1 (placed at the point where positive
electrode and separator meet). Defaults to 0.5 (in the middle).

\sphinxlineitem{show\_plot}{[}bool, optional{]}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Whether to show the plots. Default is True. Set to False if you
want to only display the plot after plt.show() has been called.

\sphinxlineitem{kwargs\_fill}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Keyword arguments: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{matplotlib.axes.Axes.fill\_between}}

Bases: {\hyperref[\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.models.equivalent_circuits.ECM:ep_bolfi.models.equivalent_circuits.ECM}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ECM}}}}}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Constant Phase Element (CPE). exponent is in (0, 1{]}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Impedance is phase\sphinxhyphen{}shifted by a constant factor n.
Nyquist plot looks like C, but rotated by (1 \sphinxhyphen{} n) * 90°.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Models imperfect capacitors. Hence, in general use values >> 0.5.
Origins:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
surface roughness (fractal dimension),

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
distribution of reaction rates (varying activation energies),

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
varying thickness or composition of (surface) coatings,

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
non\sphinxhyphen{}uniform current distribution (n decreases towards electrode edge).

\end{itemize}

\sphinxAtStartPar
In RQ elements, the center of the semicircle rotates below the real
axis. A “true” capacitance C may be obtained via RQ = τⁿ = (RC)ⁿ.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Warburg with semi\sphinxhyphen{}infinite diffusion condition.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Represents an infinite transmission line of RC elements.
“coefficient” refers to the Warburg coefficient σ.
“characteristic” does nothing, as there is no characteristic time\sphinxhyphen{}scale.

\sphinxAtStartPar

\end{description}

\sphinxAtStartPar
)
with D\_x being the diffusion coefficients of reduced and oxidized species
and c\_x bulk concentrations (\textasciicircum{}(b)) of reduced and oxidized species.

“characteristic” refers to the ratio between thickness of the
diffusion layer and the square\sphinxhyphen{}root of the diffusivity.

Processes the model and returns a runnable solver.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In contrast to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{solversetup.solver\_setup}}, this allows for a more
verbose description of the operating conditions and should be
preferred.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{model}} – A PyBaMM model. Use one of the models in this folder.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{operation\_input}} – A list of strings which describe the operating conditions. These
exactly match the PyBaMM usage for pybamm.Experiment. Examples:
“Hold at 4 V for 60 s”, “Discharge at 1 A for 30 s”,
“Rest for 1800 s”, “Charge at 1 C for 30 s”.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{parameters}} – The parameters that the model requires as a dictionary.
Please refer to models.standard\_parameters for the names
or adapt one of the examples in parameters.models.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{submesh\_types}} – A dictionary of the meshes to be used. The keys have to

\sphinxAtStartPar
Expectation Propagation and Bayesian Optimization.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Sets up and runs these two algorithms to infer model parameters.
Use the variables \sphinxstyleemphasis{Q}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{r}, \sphinxstyleemphasis{Q\_features} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{r\_features} to copy
the state of another estimator. Do not use them in any other case.
Always use either all of them or none of them.

\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{simulators}} – A list of functions that take one argument: a dictionary of
combined \sphinxstyleemphasis{fixed\_parameters} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{free\_parameters}. They
return the simulated counterpart to the experimental data.
Most of the time, one function will be sufficient.
Additional functions may be used to combine simulators which
each give a subset of the total experimental method.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{experimental\_datasets}} – A list of the experimental data. Each entry corresponds to
the simulator in \sphinxstyleemphasis{simulators} with the same index and has
the same structure as its output.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{feature\_extractors}} – A list of functions which each take the corresponding data
entry and return a list of numbers, which represent its
reduced features.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{fixed\_parameters}} – Dictionary of parameters that stay fixed and their values.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{free\_parameters}} – Dictionary of parameters which shall be inferred and their
initial guesses or, more accurately, their expected values.
Please note that these values live in the transformed space.
Optionally, the values may be a 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuple where the second
entry would be the variance of that parameter. For finer
tuning with covariances, use \sphinxstyleemphasis{initial\_covariance} (will take
precedence). Alternatively, you may set
\sphinxstyleemphasis{free\_parameters\_boundaries} to set the expectation values
and variances by confidence intervals.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{initial\_covariance}} – Initial covariance of the parameters. Has to be a symmetric
matrix (list of list or numpy 2D array). A reasonable simple
choice is to have a diagonal matrix and set the standard
deviation σᵢ of each parameter to half of the distance
between initial guess and biggest/smallest value that shall
be tried. If the diagonal entries are σᵢ² and the bounds are
symmetric, the probability distribution of each parameter is
95\% within these bounds. Please note that the same does not
hold for the whole probability distribution.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{free\_parameters\_boundaries}} – Optional hard boundaries of the space in which optimal
parameters are searched for. They are given as a dictionary
with values as 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuples with the left and right boundaries.
Boundaries need to be given for either none or all
parameters. If None are given, boundaries will be set by
\sphinxstyleemphasis{boundaries\_in\_deviations} relative to the covariance.
The default then is the 95 \% confidence ellipsoid.
If neither \sphinxstyleemphasis{initial\_covariance} nor \sphinxstyleemphasis{free\_parameters} set
the covariance, this parameter sets it according to the
example in the description of \sphinxstyleemphasis{initial\_covariance}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{boundaries\_in\_deviations}} – When <= 0, the boundaries are set as described above.
When > 0, the boundaries are this multiple of the standard
deviation. This scales with the shrinking covariance
as the algorithm progresses. \sphinxstyleemphasis{free\_parameters\_boundaries}
takes precedence, i.e., the covariance gets set and then the
boundaries in the optimization are in standard deviations.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{Q}} – If you want to restore a previous EP\sphinxhyphen{}BOLFI instance from a
dump of its data (see “result\_to\_json” method), put the
\sphinxstyleemphasis{Q} attribute stored therein into this parameter.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{r}} – Same as \sphinxstyleemphasis{Q}, but use the \sphinxstyleemphasis{r} attribute.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{Q\_features}} – Same as \sphinxstyleemphasis{Q}, but use the \sphinxstyleemphasis{Q\_features} attribute.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{r\_features}} – Same as \sphinxstyleemphasis{Q}, but use the \sphinxstyleemphasis{r\_features} attribute.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{transform\_parameters}} – Optional transformations between the parameter space that is
used for searching for optimal parameters and the model
parameters. Any missing free parameter is not transformed.
The values are 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuples. The first entry is a function
taking the search space parameter and returning the model
parameter. The second entry is the inverse function.
For convenience, any value may also be one of the following:
\sphinxhyphen{} ‘none’ => (identity, identity)
\sphinxhyphen{} ‘log’ => (exp, log)
Please note that, for performance reasons, the returned
inferred values are directly back\sphinxhyphen{}transformed from the mean
of the internal standard distribution. This means that they
represent the median of the actual distribution.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{weights}} – Optional weights to rescale multi\sphinxhyphen{}dimensional features.
Has no effect on scalar features, as BOLFI is invariant with
respect to constant or linear transformations.
A list of lists of numpy.array which correspond to the
\sphinxstyleemphasis{feature\_extractors}. The numpy.array have to have the same
length as their feature, and will be multiplied entry\sphinxhyphen{}wise
onto the feature before taking the distance to the data.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{display\_current\_feature}} – A list of functions. Each corresponds to a feature extractor
with the same index. Given an index of the array of its
features, this returns a short description of it.
If None is given, only the index will be shown in the output.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{fixed\_parameter\_order}} – Establish a numerical order to the parameter names. This
prevents errors arising from internal reordering of the
dictionaries. Only necessary when using the same model in
different contexts.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{seed}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Runs Expectation Propagation together with BOLFI.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This function can be called multiple times; the estimation will
take off from where it last stopped.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Enable parallelization in ELFI (for details, see \sphinxurl{https://}
\# elfi.readthedocs.io/en/latest/usage/parallelization.html):
\sphinxhyphen{} For local multithreading with all cores:
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{elfi.set\_client('multiprocessing')}}
\end{quote}
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
For scaling to clusters:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{elfi.set\_client('ipyparallel')}}

\end{itemize}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{bolfi\_initial\_evidence}} – Number of evidence samples BOLFI will take for each feature
before using Bayesian Optimization sampling. Default:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1 + 2 ** number of estimated parameters}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{bolfi\_total\_evidence}} – Number of evidence samples BOLFI will take for each feature
in total (including initial evidence). Default:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{2 * bolfi\_initial\_evidence}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{bolfi\_posterior\_samples}} – Effective number of samples BOLFI will take from the
posterior distribution. These are then used to fit a
Gaussian to the posterior. Fit convergence scales with 1/√n.
Default: I² + 3 * I with I as the number of
estimated parameters. This is the number of the
metaparameters of the underlying probability distribution
times 2. The “times 2” considers the warmup samples.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ep\_iterations}} – The number of iterations of the Expectation Propagation
algorithm, i.e., the number of passes over each feature.
Default: 3.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ep\_dampener}} – The linear combination factor of the posterior calculated by
BOLFI and the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}prior. 0 means no dampening, i.e., the
pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}prior gets replaced by the posterior. For values up
to 1, that fraction of the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}prior remains in each
site update. Default: with a as the number of features and
b as \sphinxstyleemphasis{ep\_iterations}, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1 \sphinxhyphen{} a * (1 \sphinxhyphen{} ᵃᵇ√final\_dampening)}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{final\_dampening}} – Alternative way to set \sphinxstyleemphasis{ep\_dampener}. 0 means no dampening.
For values up to 1, that fraction of the prior remains after
the whole estimation. Default: if \sphinxstyleemphasis{ep\_dampener} is not set,
0.5. Else, \sphinxstyleemphasis{ep\_dampener} takes precedence.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ep\_dampener\_reduction\_steps}} – Number of iterations over which the \sphinxstyleemphasis{ep\_dampener} gets
reduced to 0. In each iteration, an equal fraction of it
gets subtracted. Set to a negative number to disable the
reduction. Default: \sphinxhyphen{}1.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{gelman\_rubin\_threshold}} – Optional threshold on top of the effective sample size.
Values close to one indicate a converged estimate of the
pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}posteriors. Never set to exactly one.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ess\_ratio\_sampling\_from\_zero}} – Threshold in the ratio of effective sample size to samples
in the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}posterior estimation, at which the sampling
defaults to starting at the center of the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}prior. Set
higher than \sphinxstyleemphasis{ess\_ratio\_resample} to disable this behaviour.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ess\_ratio\_resample}} – Threshold in the ratio of effective sample size to samples
in the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}posterior estimation, at which before sampling
the model gets resampled. Set higher than \sphinxstyleemphasis{ess\_ratio\_abort}
to disable this behaviour.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ess\_ratio\_abort}} – Threshold in the ratio of effective sample size to samples
in the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}posterior estimation, at which the sampling
aborts and the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}posterior update is skipped.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{max\_heuristic\_steps}} – The heuristics that are set by the \sphinxstyleemphasis{ess\_ratio\_x} arguments
could effectively run forever. This parameter limits the
amount of times these heuristics get employed in on EP
iteration before it terminates.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{posterior\_sampling\_increase}} – The factor by which the ratio of the effective sample size
to samples in the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}posterior estimation is multiplied
each loop (cumulatively). Never set to exactly one or lower,
as it might result in an infinite loop.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{model\_resampling\_increase}} – The factor by which \sphinxstyleemphasis{bolfi\_total\_evidence} gets multiplied
each time the model gets resampled.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{independent\_mcmc\_chains}} – The number of independent Markov\sphinxhyphen{}Chain Monte Carlo chains
that are used for the estimation of the pseudo\sphinxhyphen{}posterior.
Since we did not implement parallelization, more chains will
not be faster, but more stable.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{scramble\_ep\_feature\_order}} – True randomizes the order that the EP features are iterated
over. Their order is still consistent across EP iterations.
False uses the order that the \sphinxstyleemphasis{feature\_extractors} define.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{show\_trials}} – True plots the log of tried parameters live. Please note
that each plot blocks the execution of the program, so do
not use this when running the estimation in the background.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{verbose}} – True shows verbose error messages and logs of the estimation
process. With False, you need to get the estimation results
from \sphinxstyleemphasis{self.final\_expectation} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{self.final\_covariance}.
Default: True.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{seed}} – Optional seed that is used in the RNG. If None is given, the
results will be slightly different each time.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The BOLFI instance of the last EP iteration. As such, it
contains the Posterior of the overall inference procedure.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{visualize\_parameter\_distribution() (ep\_bolfi.optimization.EP\_BOLFI.EP\_BOLFI method)@\spxentry{visualize\_parameter\_distribution()}\spxextra{ep\_bolfi.optimization.EP\_BOLFI.EP\_BOLFI method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{visualize\_parameter\_distribution}}}{}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Plots the features and visualizes the correlation.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Please note that this function requires that the output of the
individual simulators and the individual experimental data give
an x\sphinxhyphen{} and y\sphinxhyphen{}axis when indexed with {[}0{]} and {[}1{]}, respectively.
Lists of lists in {[}0{]} and {[}1{]} with segmented data works as well.
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{EP\_BOLFI.run}} does not have these restrictions.
Visualizes the comparison that EP\_BOLFI was set up to infer
model parameters with. May be used to check if everything works
as intended. Additionally, the 95\% confidence error bounds for
the parameters are visualized to check for reasonable bounds.
If called after \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{run}}, the expected parameter set, the
correlation and error bounds are from the finished estimation.

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Normalizes sampling to a standard normal distribution.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In order to help BOLFI to work efficiently with the least amount of
setup required, this class mediates between the model parameters
and a standard normal distribution for sampling. In a sense, the
simulator output gets transformed into covariance eigenvectors.

Example: cycling measurements from Basytec devices. Their format
resembles a csv file with one title and one header comment line.
So the first line will be ignored and the second used for headers.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{path}} – The full or relative path to the measurement file.

\sphinxAtStartPar

arrive at the first dataset line.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{headers}} – A dictionary. Its keys are the indices of the columns
which are to be read in. The corresponding values are there to
tell this function which kind of data is in which column. The
following format has to be used: “<name> {[}<unit>{]}” where “name”
is “U” (voltage), “I” (current), or “t” (time) and “unit” is
“V”, “A”, “h”, “m” ,or “s” with the optional prefixes “k”, “m”,
“µ”, or “n”. This converts the data to prefix\sphinxhyphen{}less SI units.
Additional columns may be read in with keys not in this format.
The columns for segments and sign correction are only given by
\sphinxstyleemphasis{segment\_column} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{correction\_column}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{delimiter}} – The delimiter string between datapoints. The default is “       “.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{decimal}} – The string used for the decimal point. Default: “.”.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{datatype}} – Default is “cycling”, where cycling information is assumed in
the file. “static” will trigger the additional extraction of
exponential decays that are relevant to e.g. GITT.
“impedance” will treat the file as an impedance measurement
with frequencies and impedances instead of time and voltage.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{segment\_column}} – The index of the column that stores the index
of the current segment. If it changes from one data point to the
next, that is used as the dividing line between two segments.
Default is \sphinxhyphen{}1, which returns the dataset in one segment.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{segments\_to\_process}} – A list of indices which give the segments that shall be

have the same positive sign as charge currents in the file, use

\sphinxAtStartPar

\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{max\_number\_of\_lines}} – The maximum number of dataset lines that are to be read in.

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.utility.fitting_functions.OCV_fit_function:ep_bolfi.utility.fitting_functions.OCV_fit_function}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ep\_bolfi.utility.fitting\_functions.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{OCV\_fit\_function}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{E\_OCV}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{o}{*}\DUrole{n}{args}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{z}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{1.0}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{T}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{298.15}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{individual}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{fit\_SOC\_range}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{rescale}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
The OCV model from “A parametric OCV model”.


\subparagraph{Reference}
\label{\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.utility.fitting_functions.OCV_fit_function:reference}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
C. R. Birkl, E. McTurk, M. R. Roberts, P. G. Bruce and D. A. Howey.
“A Parametric Open Circuit Voltage Model for Lithium Ion Batteries”.
Journal of The Electrochemical Society, 162(12):A2271\sphinxhyphen{}A2280, 2015
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{param E\_OCV}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The voltages for which the SOCs shall be evaluated.

\sphinxlineitem{param {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}args}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A list which length is dividable by three. These are the
parameters E₀, a and Δx from the paper referenced above in the
order (E₀\_0, a\_0, Δx\_0, E₀\_1, a\_1, Δx\_1…). If \sphinxstyleemphasis{fit\_SOC\_range}
is True, two additional arguments are at the front (see there).
The last Δx\_j may be omitted to force ∑ⱼ Δx\_j = 1.

\sphinxlineitem{param z}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The charge number of the electrode interface reaction.

\sphinxlineitem{param T}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The temperature of the electrode.

\sphinxlineitem{param individual}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If True, the model function summands are not summed up.

\sphinxlineitem{param fit\_SOC\_range}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If True, this function takes two additional arguments at the
start of \sphinxstyleemphasis{args} that may be used to adjust the data SOC range.

\sphinxlineitem{param rescale}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If True, the expected \sphinxstyleemphasis{args} now contain the slopes of the
summands at their respective origins instead of a. Formula:
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{a / slope = \sphinxhyphen{}4 * (k\_B / e) * T / (Δx * z)}}.

\sphinxlineitem{returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The evaluation of the model function. This is the referenced fit
function on a linearly transformed SOC range if \sphinxstyleemphasis{fit\_SOC\_range}
is True. If \sphinxstyleemphasis{individual} is True, the individual summands in the
model function get returned as a list.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ep\_bolfi.utility.fitting\_functions.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{fit\_OCV}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{SOC}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{OCV}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{N}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{4}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{SOC\_range\_bounds}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{(0.2, 0.8)}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{SOC\_range\_limits}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{(0.0, 1.0)}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{z}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{1.0}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{T}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{298.15}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{inverted}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{True}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{fit\_SOC\_range}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{True}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{distance\_order}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{2}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{weights}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{initial\_parameters}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{minimize\_options}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Fits data to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{fitting\_functions.OCV\_fit\_function}}.

\sphinxAtStartPar
In addition to the fit itself, a model\sphinxhyphen{}based correction
to the provided SOC\sphinxhyphen{}OCV\sphinxhyphen{}data is made. If \sphinxstyleemphasis{SOC} lives in a
(0,1)\sphinxhyphen{}range, the correction is given as its transformation to the
(SOC\_start, SOC\_end)\sphinxhyphen{}range given as the first two returned numbers.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{SOC}} – The SOCs at which measurements were made.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{OCV}} – The corresponding open\sphinxhyphen{}circuit voltages.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{N}} – The number of phases of the OCV model.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{SOC\_range\_bounds}} – Optional hard upper and lower bounds for the SOC correction from
the left and the right side, respectively, as a 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuple. Use it
as a limiting guess for the actual SOC range represented in the
measurement. Has to be inside (0.0, 1.0). Set to (0.0, 1.0) to
effectively disable SOC range estimation.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{SOC\_range\_limits}} – Optional hard lower and upper bounds for the SOC correction from
the left and the right side, respectively, as a 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuple. Use it
if you know that your OCV data is incomplete and by how much.
Has to be inside (0.0, 1.0). Set to (0.0, 1.0) to allow the
SOC range estimation to assign datapoints to the asymptotes.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{z}} – The charge number of the electrode interface reaction.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{T}} – The temperature of the electrode.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{inverted}} – If True (default), the widely adopted SOC convention is assumed.
If False, the formulation of “A parametric OCV model” is used.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{fit\_SOC\_range}} – If True (default), a model\sphinxhyphen{}based correction to the provided
SOC\sphinxhyphen{}OCV\sphinxhyphen{}data is made.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{distance\_order}} – The order of the norm of the vector of the distances between OCV
data and OCV model. Default is 2, i.e., the Euclidean norm.
1 sets it to absolute distance, and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{float('inf')}} sets it to
maximum distance. Note that 1 will lead to worse performance.

\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Calculates a smoothed spline with derivatives.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Note: the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{roots}} method of a spline only works if it is cubic,
i.e. of third order. Each \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{derivative}} reduces the order by one.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{x}} – The independent variable.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{y}} – The dependent variable (“plotted over \sphinxstyleemphasis{x}”).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{order}} – Interpolation order of the spline.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{splits}} – Optional tuning parameter. A list of points between which
splines will be fitted first. The returned spline then is a fit
of these individual splines.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{w}} – Optional list of weights. Works best if \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1 / w}} approximates
the standard deviation of the noise in \sphinxstyleemphasis{y} at each point.
Defaults to the SciPy default behaviour of
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{scipy.interpolate.UnivariateSpline}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{s}} – Optional tuning parameter. Higher values lead to coarser, but
more smooth interpolations and vice versa. Defaults to SciPy
default behaviour of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{scipy.interpolate.UnivariateSpline}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{display}} – If set to True, the fit parameters of the spline will be printed
to console. If possible, a monomial representation is printed.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{derivatives}} – The derivatives of the spline to also include in the return.
Default is 0, which gives the spline. 1 would give the spline,
followed by its derivative. Can not be higher than spline order.
Derivatives are only continuous when \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{derivatives < order}}.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A smoothing spline in the form of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{scipy.UnivariateSpline}}.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\paragraph{ep\_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.OCV\_from\_CC\_CV}
\label{\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.OCV_from_CC_CV:ep-bolfi-utility-preprocessing-ocv-from-cc-cv}}\label{\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.OCV_from_CC_CV::doc}}\index{OCV\_from\_CC\_CV() (in module ep\_bolfi.utility.preprocessing)@\spxentry{OCV\_from\_CC\_CV()}\spxextra{in module ep\_bolfi.utility.preprocessing}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.OCV_from_CC_CV:ep_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.OCV_from_CC_CV}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ep\_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{OCV\_from\_CC\_CV}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{charge}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{cv}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{discharge}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{name}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{phases}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{eval\_points}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{200}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{spline\_SOC\_range}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{(0.01, 0.99)}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{spline\_order}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{2}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{spline\_smoothing}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{0.002}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{spline\_print}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{parameters\_print}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{False}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Tries to extract the OCV curve from CC\sphinxhyphen{}CV cycling data.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{charge}} – A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cycling\_Information}} object containing the constant charge
cycle(s). If more than one CC\sphinxhyphen{}CV\sphinxhyphen{}cycle shall be analyzed, please
make sure that the order of this, cv and discharge align.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{cv}} – A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cycling\_Information}} object containing the constant voltage
part between charge and discharge cycle(s).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{discharge}} – A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cycling\_Information}} object containing the constant
discharge cycle(s). These occur after each cv cycle.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{name}} – Name of the material for which the CC\sphinxhyphen{}CV\sphinxhyphen{}cycling was measured.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{phases}} – Number of phases in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{fitting\_functions.OCV\_fit\_function}}
as an int. The higher it is, the more (over\sphinxhyphen{})fitted the model
becomes.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{eval\_points}} – The number of points for plotting of the OCV curves.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{spline\_SOC\_range}} – 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuple giving the SOC range in which the inverted
fitting\_functions.OCV\_fit\_function will be interpolated by a
smoothing spline. Outside of this range the spline is used for
extrapolation. Use this to fit the SOC range of interest more
precisely, since a fit of the whole range usually fails due to
the singularities at SOC 0 and 1. Please note that this range
considers the 0\sphinxhyphen{}1\sphinxhyphen{}range in which the given SOC lies and not the
linear transformation of it from the fitting process.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{spline\_order}} – Order of this smoothing spline. If it is set to 0, this only
calculates and plots the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{fitting\_functions.OCV\_fit\_function}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{spline\_smoothing}} – Smoothing factor for this smoothing spline. Default: 2e\sphinxhyphen{}3. Lower
numbers give more precision, while higher numbers give a simpler
spline that smoothes over steep steps in the fitted OCV curve.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{spline\_print}} – If set to either ‘python’ or ‘matlab’, a string representation
of the smoothing spline is printed in the respective format.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{parameters\_print}} – Set to True if the fit parameters should be printed to console.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar

\sphinxAtStartPar
An 8\sphinxhyphen{}tuple consisting of the following:
0: OCV\_fits
\begin{quote}

\sphinxAtStartPar
The fitted OCV curve parameters for each CC\sphinxhyphen{}CV cycle as
returned by \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{fitting\_functions.fit\_OCV}}.
\end{quote}
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{1: I\_mean}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The currents assigned to each CC\sphinxhyphen{}CV cycle (without CV).

\sphinxlineitem{2: C\_charge}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The moved capacities during the charge segment(s). This is
a list of the same length as charge, cv or discharge.

\sphinxlineitem{3: U\_charge}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The voltages during the charge segment(s). Length: same.

\sphinxlineitem{4: C\_discharge}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The moved capacities during the discharge segment(s).
Length: same.

\sphinxlineitem{5: U\_discharge}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The voltages during the discharge segment(s). Length: same.

\sphinxlineitem{6: C\_evals}
\sphinxAtStartPar
Structurally the same as C\_charge or C\_discharge, this
contains the moved capacities that were assigned to the mean
voltages of charge and discharge cycle(s).

\sphinxlineitem{7: U\_means}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The mean voltages of each charge and discharge cycle.

\end{description}


\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\paragraph{ep\_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.approximate\_confidence\_ellipsoid}
\label{\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.approximate_confidence_ellipsoid:ep-bolfi-utility-preprocessing-approximate-confidence-ellipsoid}}\label{\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.approximate_confidence_ellipsoid::doc}}\index{approximate\_confidence\_ellipsoid() (in module ep\_bolfi.utility.preprocessing)@\spxentry{approximate\_confidence\_ellipsoid()}\spxextra{in module ep\_bolfi.utility.preprocessing}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.approximate_confidence_ellipsoid:ep_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.approximate_confidence_ellipsoid}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ep\_bolfi.utility.preprocessing.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{approximate\_confidence\_ellipsoid}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{parameters}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{free\_parameters\_names}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{covariance}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{mean}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{None}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{transform\_parameters}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{\{\}}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{refinement}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{True}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{confidence}\DUrole{o}{=}\DUrole{default_value}{0.95}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Approximate a confidence ellipsoid.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Compatible with SubstitutionDict, if \sphinxstyleemphasis{parameters} is one.
The geometric approximation is a refinement of the polytope with
nodes on the semiaxes of the confidence ellipsoid. The refinement
step adds a node for each face, i.e., each sub\sphinxhyphen{}polytope with
dimension smaller by 1. This node is centered on that face and
projected onto the confidence ellipsoid.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{parameters}} – The base full parameter set as a dictionary.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{free\_parameters\_names}} – The names of the parameters that are uncertain as a list. This
parameter has to match the order of parameters in \sphinxstyleemphasis{covariance}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{covariance}} – The covariance of the uncertain parameters as a two\sphinxhyphen{}dimensional
NumPy array.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{mean}} – The mean of the uncertain parameters as a dictionary. If not
set, the values from \sphinxstyleemphasis{parameters} will be used.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{transform\_parameters}} – 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Optional transformations between the parameter space that is
used for searching for optimal parameters and the model
parameters. Any missing free parameter is not transformed.
The values are 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuples. The first entry is a function taking
the search space parameter and returning the model parameter.
The second entry is the inverse function.
For convenience, any value may also be one of the following:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
’none’ => (identity, identity)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
’log’ => (exp, log)

\end{itemize}


\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{confidence}} – The confidence within the ellipsoid. Defaults to 0.95, i.e., the
95\% confidence ellipsoid.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{refinement}} – If False, only the nodes on the semiaxes get returned. If True,
the nodes centered on the faces get returned as well.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuple where the first item is the list of all parameter set
combinations and the second the ellipsoid nodes only as a
two\sphinxhyphen{}dimensional numpy array with each node in on row.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar

\sphinxAtStartPar

\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{transform\_parameters}} – 
\sphinxAtStartPar
Optional transformations between the parameter space that is
used for searching for optimal parameters and the model
parameters. Any missing free parameter is not transformed.
The values are 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuples. The first entry is a function taking
the search space parameter and returning the model parameter.
The second entry is the inverse function.
For convenience, any value may also be one of the following:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
’none’ => (identity, identity)

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
’log’ => (exp, log)

\end{itemize}


\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{confidence}} – The confidence within the ellipsoid. Defaults to 0.95, i.e., the
95\% confidence ellipsoid.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{full\_factorial}} – \begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{When \sphinxstyleemphasis{parameters\_to\_try} is set:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If True, all parameter combinations are tried out. If False,
only each parameter is varied with the others staying fixed.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{When “covariance” is set:}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
If False, only the points on the semiaxes of the confidence
ellipsoid constitute the parameters to try. If True, the
centres of the faces of the polytope of these points get
added to the parameters to try, projected onto the surface
of the confidence ellipsoid.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}


\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{calc\_esoh}} – Passed on to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pybamm.Simulator}}, see there.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{t\_eval}} – The timepoints at which the “errorbars” shall be evaluated in s.
If None are given, the timepoints of the solutions will be
chosen.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{**kwargs}} – 
\sphinxAtStartPar
The optional parameters for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{solversetup.solver\_setup}}.


\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
A 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuple with the model solution for \sphinxstyleemphasis{parameters} as 1ˢᵗ entry.
The second entry mimics \sphinxstyleemphasis{parameters\_to\_try} with each entry in
their lists replaced by the model solution for the corresponding
parameter substitution. The second entry has one additional key
“all parameters”, where all \sphinxstyleemphasis{parameters\_to\_try} combinations are
the value.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{current\_sign}} – 1 adds SOC, \sphinxhyphen{}1 subtracts it, 0 follows the default behaviour
above.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{voltage\_sign}} – 1 subtracts the OCP, \sphinxhyphen{}1 adds it, 0 follows the default behaviour

\sphinxAtStartPar
Fits an SOC(OCV)\sphinxhyphen{}model and an OCV(SOC)\sphinxhyphen{}evaluable spline.

\sphinxAtStartPar
Exemplary fit parameters of a graphite anode:
``
E\_0\_g = np.array({[}0.35973, 0.17454, 0.12454, 0.081957{]})
γUeminus1\_g = np.array({[}\sphinxhyphen{}0.33144, 8.9434e\sphinxhyphen{}3, 7.2404e\sphinxhyphen{}2, 6.7789e\sphinxhyphen{}2{]})
a\_g = a\_fit(γUeminus1\_g)
Δx\_g = np.array({[}8.041e\sphinxhyphen{}2, 0.23299, 0.29691, 0.39381{]})\#0.22887
graphite = {[}p{[}i{]} for i in range(4) for p in {[}E\_0\_g, a\_g, Δx\_g{]}{]}
``
Exemplary fit parameters of an NMC\sphinxhyphen{}622 cathode:
``
E\_0\_NMC = np.array({[}4.2818, 3.9632, 3.9118, 3.6788{]})
γUeminus1\_NMC = np.array({[}\sphinxhyphen{}0.22022, \sphinxhyphen{}0.083146, 0.070787, \sphinxhyphen{}0.11461{]})
a\_NMC = a\_fit(γUeminus1\_NMC)
Δx\_NMC = np.array({[}0.38646, 0.28229, 0.15104, 0.26562{]})\#0.30105
NMC = {[}p{[}i{]} for i in range(4) for p in {[}E\_0\_NMC, a\_NMC, Δx\_NMC{]}{]}
``
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ax}} – The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{matplotlib.Axes}} instance for plotting.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{SOC}} – Presumed SOC points of the OCV measurement. They only need to be
precise in respect to relative capacity between measurements.
The SOC endpoints of the measurement will be fitted using the
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{fitting\_functions.OCV\_fit\_function}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{OCV}} – OCV measurements.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{name}} – Name of the material for which the OCV curve was measured.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{phases}} – Number of phases in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{fitting\_functions.OCV\_fit\_function}}.
The higher it is, the more (over\sphinxhyphen{})fitted the model becomes.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{SOC\_range\_bounds}} – Optional hard upper and lower bounds for the SOC correction from
the left and the right side, respectively, as a 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuple. Use it
as a limiting guess for the actual SOC range represented in the
measurement. Has to be inside (0.0, 1.0). Set to (0.0, 1.0) to
effectively disable SOC range estimation.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{SOC\_range\_limits}} – Optional hard lower and upper bounds for the SOC correction from
the left and the right side, respectively, as a 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuple. Use it
if you know that your OCV data is incomplete and by how much.
Has to be inside (0.0, 1.0). Set to (0.0, 1.0) to allow the
SOC range estimation to assign datapoints to the asymptotes.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{z}} – The charge number of the electrode interface reaction.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{T}} – The temperature of the electrode.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{fit}} – May provide the fit parameters if they are already known.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{eval\_SOC}} – Denotes the minimum and maximum SOC to plot the OCV curves at.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{eval\_points}} – The number of points for plotting of the OCV curves.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{spline\_SOC\_range}} – 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuple giving the SOC range in which the inverted
fitting\_functions.OCV\_fit\_function will be interpolated by a
smoothing spline. Outside of this range the spline is used for
extrapolation. Use this to fit the SOC range of interest more
precisely, since a fit of the whole range usually fails due to
the singularities at SOC 0 and 1. Please note that this range
considers the 0\sphinxhyphen{}1\sphinxhyphen{}range in which the given SOC lies and not the
linear transformation of it from the fitting process.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{spline\_order}} – Order of this smoothing spline. If it is set to 0, this only
calculates and plots the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{fitting\_functions.OCV\_fit\_function}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{spline\_print}} – If set to either ‘python’ or ‘matlab’, a string representation
of the smoothing spline is printed in the respective format.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{parameters\_print}} – Set to True if the fit parameters should be printed to console.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{inverted}} – If True (default), the widely adopted SOC convention is assumed.
If False, the formulation of “A parametric OCV model” is used.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{info\_accuracy}} – If True, some measures of fit accuracy are displayed in the
figure legend: RMSE (root mean square error), MAE (mean absolute
error) and ME (maximum error).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{normalized\_xaxis}} – If True, the x\sphinxhyphen{}axis gets rescaled to {[}0,1{]}, where \{0,1\} matches
the asymptotes of the OCV fit function.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{distance\_order}} – The argument passed to the numpy.linalg.norm of the vector of
distances between OCV data and OCV model. Default is 2, i.e.,
the Euclidean norm. 1 sets it to absolute distance.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{weights}} – Optional weights to apply to the vector of the distances between
OCV data and OCV model. Defaults to equal weights.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{initial\_parameters}} – Optional initial guess for the model parameters. If left as\sphinxhyphen{}is,
this will be automatically gleaned from the data. Use only if
you have another fit to data of the same electrode material.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{minimize\_options}} – Dictionary that gets passed to scipy.optimize.minimize with the
method \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{trust\sphinxhyphen{}constr}}. See \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{scipy.optimize.show\_options}}
with the arguments ‘minimize’ and ‘trust\sphinxhyphen{}constr’ for details.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Generates a coarse GUI for manual impedance model parameterization.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{frequencies}} – The frequencies to plot the model over.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{measured\_impedance}} – The impedance to compare against. Has to match \sphinxstyleemphasis{frequencies}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{parameters}} – The model parameters. See \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{models.analytic\_impedance}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{unknowns}} – List of parameter names that will be adjustable via sliders.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{transform\_unknowns}} – Optional parameter transformations, for e.g. log sliders.
Dictionary matching \sphinxstyleemphasis{unknowns}, with values being 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuples:
the first entry being the slider\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}value transform, and
the second entry being the value\sphinxhyphen{}to\sphinxhyphen{}slider transform.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{three\_electrode}} – With None, does nothing (i.e., cell potentials are used). If
set to either ‘positive’ or ‘negative’, instead of cell
potentials, the base for the displayed voltage will be the
potential of the ‘positive’ or ‘negative’ electrode against a
reference electrode. For placement of said reference electrode,
please refer to \sphinxstyleemphasis{dimensionless\_reference\_electrode\_location}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{dimensionless\_reference\_electrode\_location}} – The location of the reference electrode, given as a scalar
between 0 (placed at the point where negative electrode and
separator meet) and 1 (placed at the point where positive
electrode and separator meet). Defaults to 0.5 (in the middle).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{with\_dl\_and\_sei}} – If set to True, the Electrochemical Double Layer and Solid
Electrolyte Interphase models in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{models.analytic\_impedance}}
get added to the simulation.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{verbose}} – If True, each slider change triggers a log of some
characteristic model properties to stdout.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{charge}} – A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cycling\_Information}} object containing the constant charge
cycle(s). If more than one CC\sphinxhyphen{}CV\sphinxhyphen{}cycle shall be analyzed, please
make sure that the order of this, \sphinxstyleemphasis{cv}, and \sphinxstyleemphasis{discharge} align.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{cv}} – A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cycling\_Information}} object containing the constant voltage
part between charge and discharge cycle(s).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{discharge}} – A \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Cycling\_Information}} object containing the constant
discharge cycle(s). These occur after each \sphinxstyleemphasis{cv} cycle.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{name}} – Name of the material for which the CC\sphinxhyphen{}CV\sphinxhyphen{}cycling was measured.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{phases}} – Number of phases in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{fitting\_functions.OCV\_fit\_function}}.
The higher it is, the more (over\sphinxhyphen{})fitted the model becomes.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{eval\_points}} – The number of points for plotting of the OCV curves.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{spline\_SOC\_range}} – 2\sphinxhyphen{}tuple giving the SOC range in which the inverted
fitting\_functions.OCV\_fit\_function will be interpolated by a
smoothing spline. Outside of this range the spline is used for
extrapolation. Use this to fit the SOC range of interest more
precisely, since a fit of the whole range usually fails due to
the singularities at SOC 0 and 1. Please note that this range
considers the 0\sphinxhyphen{}1\sphinxhyphen{}range in which the given SOC lies and not the
linear transformation of it from the fitting process.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{spline\_order}} – Order of this smoothing spline. If it is set to 0, this only
calculates and plots the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{fitting\_functions.OCV\_fit\_function}}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{spline\_smoothing}} – Smoothing factor for this smoothing spline. Default: 2e\sphinxhyphen{}3. Lower
numbers give more precision, while higher numbers give a simpler
spline that smoothes over steep steps in the fitted OCV curve.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{spline\_print}} – If set to either ‘python’ or ‘matlab’, a string representation
of the smoothing spline is printed in the respective format.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{parameters\_print}} – Set to True if the fit parameters should be printed to stdout.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{@param ax\_ICA\_mean}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Axes}} where the Incremental Capacity Analysis of the mean
voltages of charge and discharge cycle(s) shall be plotted.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\paragraph{ep\_bolfi.utility.visualization.plot\_comparison}
\label{\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.utility.visualization.plot_comparison:ep-bolfi-utility-visualization-plot-comparison}}\label{\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.utility.visualization.plot_comparison::doc}}\index{plot\_comparison() (in module ep\_bolfi.utility.visualization)@\spxentry{plot\_comparison()}\spxextra{in module ep\_bolfi.utility.visualization}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{api/ep_bolfi.utility.visualization.plot_comparison:ep_bolfi.utility.visualization.plot_comparison}}
\pysigstartsignatures
\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ep\_bolfi.utility.visualization.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{plot\_comparison}}}{\sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{ax}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{solutions}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{errorbars}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{experiment}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{solution\_visualization={[}{]}}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{t\_eval=None}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{title=''}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{xlabel=''}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{ylabel=''}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{feature\_visualizer=<function <lambda>>}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{feature\_fontsize=12}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{interactive\_plot=False}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{output\_variables=None}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{voltage\_scale=1.0}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{use\_cycles=False}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{overpotential=False}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{three\_electrode=None}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{dimensionless\_reference\_electrode\_location=0.5}}\sphinxparamcomma \sphinxparam{\DUrole{n}{parameters=None}}}{}
\pysigstopsignatures
\sphinxAtStartPar
Tool for comparing simulation and experiment with features.

\sphinxAtStartPar
First, a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pybamm.QuickPlot}} shows the contents of \sphinxstyleemphasis{solutions}.
Then, a plot for feature visualization and comparison is generated.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ax}} – The axes onto which the comparison shall be plotted.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{solutions}} – A dictionary of \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pybamm.Solution}} objects. The key goes into
the figure legend and the value gets plotted as a line.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{errorbars}} – A dictionary of lists of either \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pybamm.Solution}} objects or
lists of the desired variable at \sphinxstyleemphasis{t\_eval} timepoints. The key
goes into the figure legend and the values get plotted as a
shaded area between the minimum and maximum.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{experiment}} – A list/tuple of at least length 2. The first two entries are the
data timepoints in s and voltages in V. The entries after that
are only relevant as optional arguments to \sphinxstyleemphasis{feature\_visualizer}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{solution\_visualization}} – This list/tuple is passed on to \sphinxstyleemphasis{feature\_visualizer} in place of
the additional entries of \sphinxstyleemphasis{experiment} for the visualization of
the simulated features.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{t\_eval}} – The timepoints at which the \sphinxstyleemphasis{solutions} and \sphinxstyleemphasis{errorbars} shall be
evaluated in {[}s{]}. If None are given, the timepoints of the
\sphinxstyleemphasis{solutions} will be collected instead.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{title}} – The optional title of the feature visualization plot.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{xlabel}} – The optional label of the x\sphinxhyphen{}axis there. Please note that the
time will be given in {[}h{]}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ylabel}} – The optional label of the y\sphinxhyphen{}axis there.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{feature\_visualizer}} – This is an optional function that takes \sphinxstyleemphasis{experiment} and returns
a list of 2\sphinxhyphen{} or 3\sphinxhyphen{}tuples. The first two entries in the tuples
are x\sphinxhyphen{} and y\sphinxhyphen{}data to be plotted alongside the other curves.
The third entry is a string that is plotted at the respective
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{(x{[}0{]}, y{[}0{]})}}\sphinxhyphen{}coordinates.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{interactive\_plot}} – Choose whether or not a browsable overview of the solution
components shall be shown. Please note that this disrupts the
execution of this function until that plot is closed, since it
is plotted in a new figure rather than in \sphinxstyleemphasis{ax}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{output\_variables}} – The variables of \sphinxstyleemphasis{solutions} that are to be plotted. When None
are specified, some default variables get plotted. The full list
of possible variables to plot are returned by PyBaMM models from
their \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_fundamental\_variables}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_coupled\_variables}}
methods. Enter the keys from that as strings in a list here.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{voltage\_scale}} – The plotted voltage gets divided by ths value. For example,
1e\sphinxhyphen{}3 would produce a plot in {[}mV{]}. The voltage given to the
\sphinxstyleemphasis{feature\_visualizer} is not affected.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}
\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{:param {\color{red}\bfseries{}use\_cycles\_}}
\sphinxAtStartPar
If True, the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.cycles}} attribute of the \sphinxstyleemphasis{solutions} is used
for the \sphinxstyleemphasis{feature\_visualizer}. Plotting is not affected.

\end{description}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{overpotential}} – If True, only the overpotential of \sphinxstyleemphasis{solutions} gets plotted.
Otherwise, the cell voltage (OCV + overpotential) is plotted.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{three\_electrode}} – By default, does nothing (i.e., cell potentials are used). If
set to either ‘positive’ or ‘negative’, instead of cell
potentials, the base for the displayed voltage will be the
potential of the ‘positive’ or ‘negative’ electrode against a
reference electrode. For placement of said reference electrode,
please refer to \sphinxstyleemphasis{dimensionless\_reference\_electrode\_location}.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{dimensionless\_reference\_electrode\_location}} – The location of the reference electrode, given as a scalar
between 0 (placed at the point where negative electrode and
separator meet) and 1 (placed at the point where positive
electrode and separator meet). Defaults to 0.5 (in the middle).

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{parameters}} – The parameter dictionary that was used for the simulation. Only
needed for a three\sphinxhyphen{}electrode output.

\end{itemize}

\sphinxlineitem{Returns}
\sphinxAtStartPar
The text objects that were generated according to
\sphinxstyleemphasis{feature\_visualizer}.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\sphinxAtStartPar
Makes sure that all items remain and all items show up.

\sphinxAtStartPar
This basically replaces \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ax.legend}} in a way that makes sure
that new items can be added to the legend without losing old ones.
Please note that only {\color{red}\bfseries{}*}handler\_map*s with class keys work correctly.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\sphinxlineitem{Parameters}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{ax}} – The axis which legend shall be updated.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{additional\_handles}} – The same input \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ax.legend}} would expect. A list of artists.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{additional\_labels}} – The same input \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ax.legend}} would expect. A list of strings.

\item {} 
\sphinxAtStartPar
\sphinxstyleliteralstrong{\sphinxupquote{additonal\_handler\_map}} – The same input \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{ax.legend}} would expect for \sphinxstyleemphasis{handler\_map}.
Please note that, due to the internal structure of the Legend
class, only entries with keys that represent classes work right.
Entries that have instances of classes (i.e., objects) for
keys work exactly once, since the original handle of them is
lost in the initialization of a \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Legend}}.

\end{itemize}

\end{description}\end{quote}
